review: This game is great has a nice story and a great difficulty curve the problem comes with the fact that the survival mode is unplayable crashing your game if you try playing it also prevents you from getting about half the achievements legitimately ( you can always get them through the achievement manager). The last update was to fix the survival mode  and it seems it may or may not work for you, most of the posts on the community tab suggest opening thew game via steam and it works but that didn't fix my experience or deleting and re-downloading the game therefore I cannot recommend the game unless this issue is fixed as survival mode is a great test of your abilities compared with the  hardest difficulty of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037429842', 'num_games_owned': 4858, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1657375365}
review:
Definitiv ein Trend seiner Zeit, mittlerweile wesentlich schw√§cher und durch das √úberma√ü an "survive the night" Horrorgames im cuten Look √ºber die Jahre in den qualitativen Hintergrund ger√ºckt - Aber es hat absolut seinen Charme. Vom Kinderbuch-men√º mit Reimen als Tipps, bis zu den niedlichen Sounds wenn die Monster die Spielzeuge fressen - Hier sind sehr viele gute und interessante Ideen, die mehr oder weniger funktionieren. Der Sprintmeter als quasi Treibstoff, der f√ºr die gesamte Nacht aufgeteilt werden muss und das Spiel bei zu ofter Benutzung VIEL gef√§hrlicher macht, ist prinzipiell eine geniale Idee, aber in der Praxis nur frustrierend... denn wir sind einfach vieeeeel zu langsam ohne. Die Map wird gegen Ende der Woche SEHR gro√ü und ohne freiz√ºgige Nutzung der Sprinttaste kommt man nirgendwo mehr rechtzeitig hin, wodurch schnell eine Frustration entstehen kann. L√§uft es ungl√ºcklich und du musst vom Dachboden zum Keller zur√ºck zum Dachboden, kannst du dich von deiner Ausdauer verabschieden, solange du es √úBERHAUPT rechtzeitig dorthin schaffst. 

2015 war die Map noch etwas simpler, da hat sich das Problem noch nicht so gezeigt, aber dadurch war es auch alles etwas monotoner. 

Das ist auch eins der gr√∂√üen Probleme dieses Subgenres, sie werden einfach sehr schnell langweilig. Viel taktische Tiefe bieten die Games nie, oft ist es einfach eine Checkliste die man ohne Nachzudenken abarbeitet - einmal im Flow k√∂nnen sich die N√§chte ENORM langwierig anf√ºhlen.. bis man kurz vorm Ende stirbt und nochmal 10 Minuten im Kreis rennt.

Das Spiel versucht hier zumindest mehr als andere Games der Richtung, die Spielzeuge die als Futter dienen sind zuf√§llig auf der Karte verteilt und k√∂nnen als Vorbereitung in der Umgebung platziert werden - ist aber effektiv fast nutzlos, au√üer es spawnen alle auf der gleichen Seite der Karte.. hier h√§tte es helfen k√∂nnen wenn sp√§tere N√§chte zus√§tzliche Betten freigeschaltet h√§tte und nicht nur "Klick hier drauf um nicht zu sterben" Mechaniken.

2015 definitiv eher ein st√§rkeres Game der Richtung, mittlerweile eher eine okaye 6/10 mit viel Downtime und langweiligen Momenten. Die Sympathie und das liebevolle Design lassen es aber trotzdem nett genug wirken um zumindest einmal bis Donnerstag oder Freitag zu spielen - F√ºr Horrorfans gibt es wie gesagt einige nette Ideen √ºber die man sich interessante Gedanken machen kann.

Retrospektive: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y5lHQzBWyvU&t=718s&ab_channel=Corrupted

review:
An indie horror game that I absolutely wish there was a sequel to.

I absolutely enjoyed the idea of killer night blights only to be seen by little children only for the older humans to not see the deadly creatures at all.

The nights were simple (Except for Saturday) and made me enjoy every moment of it. I have wished there was a sequel since the developer said that this game was made as a project. Very underrated.

review:
I'm about to doze off and all is still,
when a Night Blight peeks over my window sill.

I go to wake mommy and see a dark head,
another one's under my parents bed!

I muster my courage and brave through the dark,
so it doesn't eat dad with teeth sharp as a shark.

I hold my breath and say a few prayers,
and slowly I start creeping down all the stairs.

My toy box must be in the living room,
a sacrifice to keep my parents from their doom.

I go back up the stairs with my favorite toy truck,
he's gone from the bed and that means...

author: {'steamid': '76561197997678124', 'num_games_owned': 1630, 'num_reviews': 443, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1607433854}
review:
Fun game! The RNG can be brutal. 

My biggest nitpick is how clunky and awful jumping on top of objects is. Aside from that, it's fun to run around the house feeding the blights toys and keeping them locked in cabinets. 

I don't think I'll ever beat this one, but I'll keep trying.

Just a hair on the pricey side for a 4 year old game that is mostly RNG. I'd say purchase on sale. $4.99 would be a better price. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198170405854', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1671937705}
review:
If scary games make yours a good day,
then Night Blights is surely a treat to play.

Its jumpscares are frightening and not always expected
its atmosphere and silence are very effective.

Learning the game is simple at first -
the more nights you win, the more house to traverse.

With every new night comes a brand new mechanic
to further increase the challenge and panic.

The challenge is balanced and never too easy;
through trial and error you'll gain victory.

Should you make a mistake that leads to your doom,
you'll learn what went wrong and save you from gloom.

Many rare chances and events exist,
to add mystery and fear in the midst.

It's easy to learn, not easy to master;
you must succeed to prevent disaster.

Should you buy and play this game? Maybe.
As long as you are not a big baby.

I give this game a 9 out of 10. 
Would get eaten by night blights again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228190400', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 215, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1591540373}
review:
Definitely not my cup of tea, but definitely in its semplicity not as bad as I did expect when I installed it. I got it out of some mysterious bundle I did forget about, and as usual, between longer games i do play smaller ones out of my library that i do not know nothing about.
It's a bit boring for sure, it's all bout doing 2-3 actions and moving around a house in the darkness as "fast" as possible. Considering that it's so simple and basic though, through a decent use of light and sounds it managed to create a bit of tension, more than i thought. It's not a horror game definitely, but achieves its scope.
A pity that going around the house repeating the same chores and getting tired fast felt awful very fast, but i didn't uninstall with a bad feeling in mind. Gets a 60/100 from me, would not recommend but it's not that bad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198355753138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1677257487}
review:
This light-hearted Indie game is an absolute delight to play. The lack of atmospheric noise makes hearing "Feed Me" all the more terrifying and unexpected. I would love to see the Night Blights make a return, even if it's in a little mini game such as that Blight Invaders arcade I saw. These creatures are adorable yet horrifying, and the amount of easter eggs spread across the house and random events let you know that the developers had a lot of fun making the game and enjoy their work.
Night Blights is an absolute treat and scary delight to play!
And Teddy Bear is an evil Master Mind

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 1111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1528898892}
review:
This game is probably best described as a first person micromanagement game where you play a young child awake late at night protecting your family from jump-scare monsters called "Night Blights".   If this sounds familiar to 2014's Five Nights at Freddies, you'd be right. 

Jobs in the game involve keeping wardrobes and the refrigerator closed, and doing some limited platform jumping to find and drag toys around to feed Night Blights hiding under the beds.   If you don't keep up with the various jobs you have, then the monsters eat you, your family, and give you jump scares. 

For an indy game the graphics are tolerable, but they're not competing well with FNAF.   If I had the option to give a middling score to this, I would, but as Chris Lambert said in Highlander, there can be only one.    In this case, which jump scare based game should be recommended?  Not this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198830208863', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1682803263}
review:
I played the free version on GameJolt, and a week later I bought this.  haven't had the time to beat the game yet, as I purchased this today, but it was a worthwhile purchase at $5.

UPDATE
After having beat the game twice, and getting through post-game (minus the survival mode that is currently unplayable, so if you care about your achievement ratio, then don't buy), I'm happy to say this is one of my favorite games on Steam. It's a very skillfully made horror game with a unique concept. This is achieved through combining familiar mechanics from other games. These include: increasing the number of things you have to manage throughout the night as levels go on (FNAF) a faster kind of movement that decreases the more you use it (Slender) and, most importantly (in my opinion) jumpscares that still scare you even though you 100% know they're coming (most of the time). This is also present in Outlast. Of course with any horror game said scares will become dull once you go for beating and completing the game, but they are pretty good initially.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025812458', 'num_games_owned': 1991, 'num_reviews': 445, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1516026617}
review: So first of all, Night Blights isn't a bad game. The sound design is serviceable, visuals are [i]fine[/i] and the gameplay loop is okay too. If you appreciate the time-based micromanagement where you enter and exit rooms checking things ad nauseam, then Night Blights is probably on the upper echelon of games you could play. It's still just not that appealing to me personally. So I guess whether the genre/gameplay mechanics are your thing decide if the game is worth it to you. Not the case for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198281324603', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1514316731}
review: Even though this game was exciting and terrifying at first, the difficulty spiked up WAY too much!  It became tedious and rage inducing.  I was beginning to think Night Blights was a rage game diguised as a horror game.  Only purchase this "horror" game if you don't get angry easily and don't care about wasting your money.  Even though I recieved this game as a gift, I still feel bad for making my friend waste their money.

review: Haven't gotten too deep into this, but it's ok. I think I am over my brief foray into horror games. This game has the mechanics that I think FNAF should have had. I think I might have actually liked FNAF if it played like Night Blights. The two games share in common the concept of keeping monsters out. But I found the gameplay in FNAF to not be very engaging. In this game, at least you can move around the environment. You have to perform different actions to block out the monsters. You also have to collect and stockpile toys to feed to the night Blights to appease them. I think I actually like this game more because it reminds me of how much I hate FNAF. Now I realize the sequels to FNAF might have added more involved gameplay, but I'll never know, I checked out after the first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071865132', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2142, 'last_played': 1549926690}
review:
Night Blights is a very fun, and charming, little horror game. It pulls off being simultaneously cute and stress-inducing so well, as the things you must manage drastically increase with each night. If you like jumpscare-based games, this one might be for you.

You play as a child who must defend yourself and your family from the gremlin-like Night Blights prowling around your home. You do this by closing doors, pressing various switches, and many other things each night. The game relies heavily on audio and sound cues, so playing with headphones is very much recommended. 

No matter how much I've played that Survival Mode to get that top score, the game still manages to make me paranoid when I do play it. My favorite part of the game is the amount of random little things there are to troll you; random things may open or appear to freak you out, or to open areas that you might not get a chance at on a different attempt. There's also many, many Easter eggs to other horror games and movies as well. The dev did a wonderful job on this cute little game, and while it may get a bit frustrating at times, it's overall quite silly and fun; I think it deserves a bit more attention than it gets here on Steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198311321014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1466658985}
review:
I loved the game over on GameJolt, however, I'm seriously dissapointed in paying money for this game. Not only has the game somehow disabled itself?!- it says that a newer game version is available and my copy has been disabled- the email I sent to Night Blights support has been bounced back. The email account simply doesn't seem to exist. It won't update, I've spent about 4 hours verifying and making sure it wasn't an error on the account of my computer. I deleted and redownloaded the game files, restarted my system, cleared out some uneccesary data. 

Then I changed the update for Night Blights to high priority, but it won't work and what I wanted to be fun has become severely frustrating. Until this issue is fixed, I feel obligated to warn people away from downloading the game. Stick to the demo version over on GameJolt for the time being until this gets fixed.

UPDATE:

The problem is now fixed. Kudos to the developers for responding so quickly to the problem, although, seeing how their update system penalizes people possesing older copies of the game, it does detract from my overall enjoyment. Regardless, I think it's time I talk about what I love about Night Blights. 

Although one could draw comparisons between this game and Five Nights at Freddies, it's clearly paved it's own path from it's horror-genre cousin. Playing this game always keeps you on your toes, as you listen to audio cues signaling which location you'll need to quickly visit. Constantly bombarded by creatures called Night Blights, keeping you or your family safe is no easy feet.

In this game, you control and direct the movement of a child. Level game play is also directed by a mysterious book detailing your gruesome encounters in common storybook fashion. Our poor protaginist seems to never be able to catch a break, since staying awake all night to fend of murderous and mischivious creatures must be quite taxing.

All around, it features a unique style of game play, with penalizing consequences for ignoring gameplay ques. Although lacking player custimization, it does boast an immersive environment with hidden suprises to continue its underlying sense of dread. Overall, I would recommend to a friend. In this game, it helps to be strategical, and keep the fire lit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014449427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1461523550}
review:
I played the Gamejolt version of this game, and I just started this version. You're not going to see any changes in the mechanics of the game, the core is still there. Which is a great thing. Gary has worked his ass off to get this game where it is, and it shows! Gary and I have become good aquantinces, so I've been able to see this game come from where it began, to being a popular game on Steam and I could not be more proud. 

You take the roll of a child at night, trying to protect your family from the Night Blights. To do this, you need to keep wardrobes closed and the blights fed using your toys. As you progress through the night, this is going to become more and more difficult with more mechanics being added. To add to that, the more you run..the more tired you get. If you let yourself get too tired, you will fall asleep. Ending the game and everyone dies. 

The jumpscares are completely random based on how you manage your time and energy. So you can't telegraph when the next scare is coming. This really is a gem of a game, and I hope that Gary and Trapdoor games does extremely well with the new release.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061116835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 600, 'last_played': 1594570431}
review: Its a pretty fun game. Usually when games scare me, especially when jumpscares are normal, I either just watch it and admire it from afar, or play it for a little bit before just stopping and and end up not playing it that much. With this game however, I find it to be so fun and challenging that I'll risk the jump scares because I feel like it's worth it when I survive the night. I also love the little easter eggs that are in the game. Everytime I play it, I find a new one and I just admire that the time was taken just to put a little easter egg like it in the game. The only complaint I have is that I can't look further down because if I stand right next to a toy, I have to walk away in order to pick it up. This is a major problem when I have to give a toy to a blight immediately, but I have to take the time just to step back and pick it up instead of looking more down and getting it. Other than that, the game is absolutely wonderful and I'm glad I bought it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198301407255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 262, 'last_played': 1461170269}
review:
I watched a few Youtubers play the Demo for this game and quite enjoyed it, and when found out the full release was available I decided to purchase & have a go for myself. 
As a fan of Horror games I do like this, I wouldnt say it was overly scary, however when basically relaying on sounds and having to focus I can honestly say that I have gotten a few scares from this game, especially when yo do not expect it.
As the days go on it does get more difficult as there is so many areas and aspects to listen out for.
Also I do enjoy the random actions some of the blights have so there is no way of telling what could happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041688793', 'num_games_owned': 1201, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 537, 'last_played': 1461094827}
review:
(Full Disclosure: The developer is a friend of mine and I provided some voice acting in this game. With that said, I can recommend this game in good conscience because I think it's genuinely fun, challenging and well-designed. It has a lot more content than many of its survive-the-night peers like Wick, Emily Wants To Play and Sophie's Curse, to boot.)

"Night Blights" is a survive-the-night game that combines Five Nights at Freddy's time management with 3D exploration. You play as a child, seeking to protect their family from home invasion by pesky, hungry Blight monsters who would love to eat your family but will settle for eating toys instead - provided you feed them in time. The game features seven levels in the core campaign, plus a survival mode and unlockable extras via a star rating system for each level.

I've played a lot of games in this style, some of which I mentioned in the disclaimer. Night Blights is, by far, the most content-rich of all of them. Each level brings new threats to the fold - on the first night, you'll have just a couple things to keep track of. By the second, you'll have a couple more. By the third, a couple more. 

The objectives stack as new areas of the house are unlocked, and it provides a decent challenge curve without growing repetitive. With each new challenge comes a wrench to your previous strategy, and winning subsequent nights requires adjustment. 

Like any game, Night Blights is not flawless. The platforming (Yes, there is platforming - one of the many ways this game stands out from its peers) is a little rough, and grabbing objects like toys or stools can feel too slippery. Minor complaints and personal frustrations aside, the game controls magnificently overall for a two-dev game that tries to do as much as Night Blights does.

Couple things before closing out: 1) This is not supposed to be a super-serious horror game. The main attraction for the game is gameplay and fun. 2) If you played the free GameJolt version of this game released last summer - Yes, the Steam version is MUCH different and is definitely worth $5.

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who like this style of gameplay. Come one, come all, disenfranchised FNAF fans! In all seriousness, "Night Blights" is much more than its time-management mechanics. At its core, it is a fun, light-hearted B-movie homage that was treated with plenty of care and attention to detail, and features more than enough content to warrant the price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110039295', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1464979075}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198282195854', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 276, 'last_played': 1600618178}
review: This is an awesome game. Probably one of the best Indie games on Steam. Night Blights is fun, its challenging, and it is way more polished than other games like it. This is not a jump scare simulator and it is not a super serious horror game. Also, this is not a FNAF rip off or a "puzzle horror" game that becomes easier once you figure out the pattern. Night Blights is a fun and slightly creepy survive-the-night game that will most likely scare you at some point.  It is worth every penny of the $4.99 price. I give it maybe a week before this thing blows up, so buy it now before it goes viral and the price goes up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053422627', 'num_games_owned': 2391, 'num_reviews': 1237, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1549984292}
review:
Here's my First Day on Launch Day First Impressions Livestream recording:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ELna1NrZ2oQ

I like it.  It's honestly not quite as "scary" as I'd hope for, but its pretty fun trying to survive the nights and protect your little baby bother.  Each night of the week gets progressively harder with more things to watch for being added each night such as shutting the toilet if a blight tries to come up through the toilet, and bellowing the fire to keep them from coming down the chimney.  Gotta stay alive each night from 11pm to 7am, and it keeps you busy!  ..No just standing there waiting like in the first FNAF.  It's fun!

Also the book that you read is awesome and fun to read as it talks about the new threats each night in a cool poetic fashion.  

Easily worth the $4.99 USD asking price!  One of the better FNAF games I've played on Steam!  Recommended to FNAF fans for sure!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036019909', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1460759661}
review:
Very few people can say that they have seen a game progress from development, to green light and through to Steam itself. I however can say that. I have beta tested this game for the developers many times and have gave some ideas which could possibly be in the game.

This game is great fun and for the price of it youre 100% going to get your money worth. This game has a good and in depth story line in which you have to defend your home and family against the dreaded Night Blights until the morning. But be carefull! They will try and get in from every window and escape from the cupboards and under your bed to eat your family.

The art work in this game is awesome, their are a lot of Easter Eggs for you to find but the theme is deffinatley scary and it does make you look behind you a few times. I have had some scary moments playing this game as well as great fun. I dont want to give away a lot of details.

I would highly recommend this game to everyone who wants a game they can either pick up and play now and again or someone who loves the in depth fear factor of gaming.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198066324830', 'num_games_owned': 335, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 303, 'last_played': 1461162163}
review:
Night Blights is a "Horror" Game, which at first glance looks really similiar to FNaF4, however it came out originally before FNaF4 did, and the game itself is completely different.

I've originally played this game when it was released on Gamejolt, and it was a really great experience. The Steam version is a lot more polished, has more features, and is in general a lot better, that's why I recommend buying it.

Now, the "horror" here isn't supposed to be taken COMPLETELY seriously. The game can be scary, however it focuses more on gameplay mechanics, that being scary. So if you're looking for the same horror experience  like in Amnesia or SOMA, you're out of luck.

Now, each night of the game, it becomes harder, and more ways for the Blights to enter your house are added. You will have to take strategies to where organize the toys, which path should you take first if a Blight is about to enter from 2 different entrances, and such. The fact that you have to constantly do things, or you will die, is giving a lot of tension to the game, making it more exciting, and adds to the scary factor. This game, I can guarantee, is not a jumpscare fest. 
During the nights, various things can happen, such as a painting falling, or a Blight just staring at you from the top of a staircase. These little things add a lot to games like this, and make it a lot better.
There's also a Survival mode and Free Roam mode here, which gives the game more replayability, so you can come back to it just to play for fun and try to survive the longest.

In other words, Night Blights is a Horror game which focuses more on the gameplay factor than the horror, and in result provides great gameplay, with simple, yet good mechanics.

So if you like the FNaF Games, or just want a small bit of scares, I recommend this game greatly. I only have less than a hour on Steam as of right now, but I spent a lot of time on the Gamejolt version, and I definitely say its worth it.
